Number two, in terms of the numbers, obviously, the New Zealand business has not been a growth engine for us but it is not cash flow drag or it is not earnings drag it's basically been a business that has not performed at a high ROI level but it's performed adequately given the context of what we need to do for the strength of our core domestic business here.

Right now we are getting impacted in New Zealand just like we are in Australia and other places regarding the economy, the downturn, lowered spending, slowdown in spending et cetera, so the focus continues and I can tell you that we do have our reviews, but I think there is a finite amount that you can do when you're a reseller and you don't have the broad-based platform of asset ownership. And we have made some investments there, where we have invested infrastructure, the returns look better. But at the end of the day that has not been kind of the priority of the company and the team. To divest at this stage still doesn't make sense for us to just simply because of the Trans-Tasman requirements that we have.
Is it fair to assume from that answer that you don't believe the changes in industry structure and regulation in New Zealand significantly improve the prospects for Telstra Clear?

Well to be quite frank, we still aren't clear on all of the outcomes of regulatory settings and pricing and terms and conditions and some of the issues there. We keep on waiting and I think it's now been at least a two-year process of getting clarity. And these things have to work themselves through. That's – that's – some people think it's easy to just make a decision and do paper math, but building out an infrastructure, building out correlating policy, setting the right tariffs and all that is a very complex process. They're not there yet. And so we're not going to over invest in something that we're not clear on in terms of what the real settings are.
Okay and...

I'll just make one other comment about Telstra Clear. I mean our objective is to improve the bottom line. So I mean the EBITDA is quite positive but the EBIT line is marginal, right. And we're doing things to like bringing or integrating some of the functions back here to Australia. So for example, the payroll for the Telstra Clear people pay is – the administration is out of Australia, the audit function, some of the finance functions are all brought back to Australia. So we're just trying to get that business as lean and mean in our operation sense -- operation – operating sense as possible. That's what we're trying to do.

Okay. And my other question relates to capital management. I know that you've held the dividend constant at $0.14. That's against 15.5 EPS. The cash outflow impact of the $0.14 is 1.7 billion and you've got a free cash flow of 1.9. So I'm wondering, given the confident reaffirmation of the six to seven billion forward-looking projection and the additional capacity that exists in the results that you've just announced, what the attitude is to returning more cash to shareholders, who have been held at these levels now for some years and more broadly, what the capital management policies are for Telstra given the likelihood of very strong free cash flow in the year ahead?
Could I just to address the first point as a matter of a technical point. Yes, $1.7 billion dividend; yes, 1.9 free cash, but I've got $632 million interest bill there right.

Mark, the answer is that we're obviously very confident of the transformation plan and getting to those free cash flow levels. And as we've said all along, when we reach that point in time at the end of this fiscal year, again the Board will be able to sit down and look at what's possible in terms of rewarding shareholders for their ownership of the stock. I'm not forecasting or predicting any behavior at this stage, but our job has been to give the Board lots of options and flexibility and capacity. And I think that's what's happening and as we've said all along during this, the Board has been very focused on shareholder returns and there will be a point in time, when the right time the Board looks at this and says we think we can do X, Y or Z. And beyond that I won't say much more. But, I think the calculation of lots of free cash, gives Boards lots of options.
Thank you.

Laurent Horrut, sorry, JPMorgan. So I understand from your comments you're saying you're not engaged with any conversation with the government anymore on NBN. Do you have any visibility at all in terms of what maybe in the making in terms of where the government is going to be thinking NBN model.

Actually I don't. I mean, again I don't spend a lot of time, worrying about it, thinking about it because as you've probably heard me say before Laurent, customers decide who they do business with. Customers make the purchase decisions regardless of what governments or regulators say. Now as David Quilty said in his speech two days ago. We're open to a call. We're open to conversation. And what I mean by that is just, this has being something we think, we could do – we could do well. But, again we don't know the process it's been very protected, quite process and we respect the process.

Isn't that just a worry, just in – in a sense that here's a $5 billion investments with government putting major investment, major money into it and that's going to define the economics of this business for the next 10 years. And Telstra the incumbent operator in Australia has no visibility whatsoever on this process.

Laurent there is a – I'm sure you lived around the world and looked at other places around the world. There are lots of examples of paper processors that never work out in reality. The degree of difficulty of building, the degree of difficulty of financing, the great degree of difficulty of operating, those are variables that on paper get way under estimated.

It takes time to build, it takes time to engineer, it takes time to construct, it takes time to turn out, it takes time to win customers and as you progress saw in a speech I gave in January, we estimated impacts and they're dramatically different than any impacts that you've estimated because you've got a what I call a very optimistic view of what people can do, or we do as we look at what reality is and degree of difficulty.

Okay. Just another question, were you a bit surprised at the level of cycle in the business and the magnitude of the slowdown since the Investor Day? At the Investor Day you sort of gave confident sort of – the message was reasonably optimistic although you did flag there were some softness. Were you surprised by the magnitude of that slowdown since that point?

Well, again as you said we flagged it pretty clearly back then that as of – at that point it was September reporting period and we had not seen a lot of impact. But as we have all seen now looking across all industries whether it be banking, retail, construction whatever here in Australia, everybody has hit the wall in this last period of time, which is why we said, we will always be prudent in terms pf how we give guidance. At that point of time, we weren't changing, didn't have enough data. Now we have, as John pointed out and I pointed out, we have a pretty significant drop in PSTN calling and as you know that's a profitable part of – disproportionately profitable part of our business. Can we do things about it? I think we can, and you'll see us executing around that. But it's hit us like it's hit every other company around the world.
Okay. Ian before we go to you, we have some calls on the phone or on the line here, so I'm going to ask the operator to give me one of those calls.
Thank you. We have a question from Christian Guerra, Goldman Sachs.

Hi. Good morning and thanks for your time and congratulations on the results. I have just three questions for you this morning, Sol and John. Firstly I guess onto some of the IT transformation you've made some comments during the presentation about some issues during the period with the call center volumes and higher than usual customer queries et cetera, et cetera. Just wondering is there any change to the targets in terms of customer migration, cost savings, platforms, switch-offs, et cetera?

My second question is on the guidance of fiscal '10. Again you've said in the presentation today that some things happened in the period that surprised you and clearly the macro is one of those. Just wondering if you could still sit on to how much conservatism or fat you've actually built into those targets.

And my third question is actually a question for you Sol on your departure. Just wondering I guess how you thought about that, in terms of the timing given that you've basically done the hard work I think over the last three years and really the benefits start coming through in the next couple of years and I guess it's a little bit surprising that you're not going to be there to deliver those fiscal '10 numbers in August, next year. Thanks.

Okay, Christian, regarding the call center volumes and all the associated questions on, does this impact what we communicated back in November of this year and November of last year the answer is no. Are there delays in terms of our systems? The answer is no. So, let me just take a little bit of time and explain again what – when we talk about what's happened in the bubble here of call volumes that affected our channels.

It's not about systems, I talked about 200 plus million records that we're processing everyday and the million – tens of millions of bills and other things. Systems are working fine. What happens is that, if you are a customer and you're used to quarterly bills, and you now get a monthly bill, it's different. And so what happens is that stimulates calls and call volumes. I said this I think back in November, that what happens is that in my experience because I have done this twice before is that you go through a cycle of two or three bill periods, where customers are calling and you get accelerated volumes into channels.

The second thing is, is that we changed our bill formats, so when you are migrating six, seven million customers on to a new platform and there is new bill format. A percentage of those customers then have questions. And what happens then is that they call into our call centers, and they start filling up what you normally staff for in terms of the volumes. We anticipated some of that, not to say that we didn't forecast for some of that increased volume. But what happens is, is that if you have an acceleration of call volume and a customer calls in at a certain point of time, and the average speed of answer is low and you're on hold for a while, you'll generally hang up and you'll call back again. And if you hit at another peak period you'll generally hang up and call back again. So what happens is that you go through this, this period of time where you've got a lot of accelerated call volumes and you don't have essentially enough capacity to handle it till you work it through.

Unfortunately, I don't know of any other way because I've, like I said, I've done this twice before, you just work through it in two or three bill cycles. Customers get used to it, they get their bills explained, they understand it and then you move on. And that's the way it works.

So as I said before, we're now on the other side of it. We've climbed the kind of the high end of it and now we're working through the other way. We have other migrations. We have another major release that's coming in this half. And we have some other big releases in the latter part of the year as we articulated back in November. So all of that work continues, all the migration work continues as we talked about back in November. And the retirement of systems, Christian to your part of your question that will continue. We've retired over 400 systems already, 450 or so. We've already retired a whole large number and we're going to continue to retire more. But not all the cost take out is just at the very end. We've got cost take out as we reduce volumes, as we reduce some other work and attention that goes on to these legacy systems.

So that's all still in train and that's part of what I said, Tom Lamming, John McInerney, they've got tagged, they've got a whole work plan around that and you just have to work through that. So none of that essentially changes.

In terms of your question about – I won't use the word "fat" – in your – the '10 objectives because we don't build fat into targets. It's a best view that we have. We are – we have been pretty optimistic about stimulating growth which back in '05 Christian you may remember most people were skeptical about the growth rates that we said we were going to generate and what the consensus view at that point of time, which was about negative one or negative 2% growth over the period of time; we've generated that.

As we look at the cost side and the cost take out, we believe that we have plenty of opportunity to take out more costs. We've now achieved the 10,000 – we've crossed over the 10,000 threshold in terms of FTE reduction that we talked about, 10 to 12,000. It was a point of discussion at our Investor Day. Some people asked the question, are you backing off of your targets? because we reminded everybody of 10 to 12,000. Well, we've now crossed over 10,000. We've got more to go. There will be more that will happen as part of a plan that's underway.

So the long answer to your – or shortening the answer to your question, Christian, about FY '10 is the management team has very specific targets about how to get to these numbers, not to say that it won't be difficult, not to say that people aren't going to be working hard, to get to there but we think that they're achievable. Can a horrible economy, if we go into a true recession, depression kind of environment, would that change some of the guidance and some of the views? The answer is absolutely. But that's not part of our view at this stage.

And then in terms of the final part, your departure, wouldn't it be nice to stick around til when all the fruits of all the labor are there? The answer is yes, but that was never part of the plan at least for me personally; my family and I think the Board understood that. We just reached the point yesterday, where as we talked and as we sat down and we visited about, when is the right time. I and the Board both felt, now is the best time to make that transition.

I want to give the Board enough time to find the right successor, to go through the right process and also that we don't lose any momentum while they're doing that. And as I said, earlier in one of the other answers, the Board is as committed to hitting the numbers as anybody. So, continuity, focus, none of that changes.

And just to clarify on the fiscal target there. I think John said in the presentation, on the fiscal '10 targets. John mentioned that, you're now expecting to come in at the lower end of the target. So that's – so we should interpret that as being wholly and solely due to the softening macro environment and as opposed to any sort of the reduction in your cost out targets?
That's correct.
That's exactly right, Christian. I had to take into account the softening. So, that's why I say they're at the low end.
That's great. Thanks for your time.
Okay. We'll take another question on the calls and then we'll go back to Ian here.
Thank you. Next question is from Sameer Chopra, Deutsche Bank.

Good morning gentleman. I had two questions, if I may. The first one, any further room for head count saves, seeing as you've already hit your transformation targets for 2010, and congratulations on that. And the second one is your guidance, are we still aiming for 5 to $800 million of cost out in the OpEx line?

In terms of the head count, the answer is yes, that's why we set the target of 10 to 12000. We think that there is more that will come naturally and what I mean by naturally is, is that we talked in terms of full time equivalents. And we do a lot of contracting, we do a lot of other work that's been part of our transformation and a lot of that work will go away as we turn up systems and as we shut down systems and that will be part of the story. Part of the story will be productivity, continued productivity increases and again last time you've heard us talk about our field force productivity improvements of being nearly 50% over the last three years. And I think you're going to see some pretty dramatic productivity improvements as we go forward in the front-end of the business as well.

In terms of the cost out, the 500 to 800, the answer is absolutely because John, a year-ago in November, and then this past November, spent time trying to help everybody understand how we get to these EBITDA margins and the free cash flows are cost structure points that we want to get to. So the answer to that is simply, yes.
So, one of the reasons for that question was, with the retail Aussie dollars I was wondering whether that was impacting input costs, particularly cost of good sold?

Well, not to a large extent, the big thing impacting out cost of goods and this has worked I think to our benefit, this year as you heard John go through the numbers. The volumes on handset sales are down dramatically because we had the big migration from CDMA to Next G, over the last year and half or so. And we've gone past that peak and now we are into another era where we're going to back to these questions about driving voice, driving more ARPU, the growth, we are into another era of the migration now where we're going to see a lot more smart phone sales, we are going to see a lot more usage that gets driven off of that, we have lots of great data. We talk a lot about iPhones, we talk a lot about Blackberry Bolds, though we can also talk about our HTC products and other products that are out there, that are driving a lot of usage, so COGS is affected to some extent but not to a great extent, so far.
Thank you.
Ian?

I have two questions Sol. First, is there any evidence yet the -- or perhaps indications that the growth in wireless broadband is having an effect on fixed broadband, subscriber numbers or revenues. And secondly, just want to explore the margin in Sensis and what's its impact is on the overall group's long-term margin trend. A couple of years ago, Sensis margins, EBITDA margins about 50%, were above the group level? They've fallen to 45%, fallen 330 basis points in the last year. Still above the group level, but I think one of you said that online margins were trending up which suggest the print margins are trending down and perhaps the two meet somewhere in the middle around 40%. That will be below the group margin next year then.

First of all, that's bit of a drag isn't it on the long term margin trend if Sensis margins are heading down that's 7 or 8% of revenue. And secondly, isn't kind of symptomatic of what's happening generally that we are moving more into this online world where the cost structure is more complex, there is more content cost and complexity and so on. That doesn't -- what is happening in Sensis perhaps presage what's going to happen in the wider business in terms of the margin trend?

No actually, Ian. I think it's important to look back a couple of years ago as you did. But I understand why, the margin has gone down you know. Part of what we went through was a period of time when our print business was in decline. And Bruce and the team and myself, we kind of made a decision that we need to kind of regenerate, and reinvigorate that business. So Bruce undertook what he called Project Morph, which is kind of -- kind of IT transformation of the business that enables a different experience but also enables cost take out. That's ahead of Bruce in terms of his operating plan. And what I mean is timeframe wise. We also invested in some additional distribution of books, and other capabilities out in the market, opening up local offices so that we can compete more effectively given the kinds of margins that we generate, so if anything our margins are going to be going up. If you look at the aggregate numbers of Sensis they really bias downward by a couple of businesses and whether it would be Trading Post, which we've talked about before and the mapping business. And then obviously the new addition on the China businesses which as they grow, they will get to scale. But I think the interesting point to your question about online, is it our online businesses are generating higher margins than what you see in the broader industry. A long answer, short answer is now; I think that margins will continue to be healthy in the business. We're just going through again an investing period and a changing the mix where that's had some dilution for a point in time.
And wireless broadband? Is it having an effect on fixed broadband subscription?

You know, Ian in terms of wireless broadband. I probably can't stand here and say that there isn't some impact in terms of substitution because there probably is with certain segments. But in terms of having a material change in terms of our view with the business, the answer is no. If you look at fixed, what we've now reached is about a 60% penetration point. But we had a lot of growth over the last three, four years in terms of that fixed portion of the market. The wireless side is now new and it's exciting and we keep on making it more exciting with more speed, more throughput and a better experience.

So you're going to see growth rates on wireless broadband being much higher than on fixed, as the market continues to evolve. And then its going to become once penetration levels get probably in a year to two years much higher, then you're going to see what I would call, how do you keep on growing at ARPU, on it? much like which you see with us and what we do on our fixed broadband which is continuing to grow ARPU.
Thank you.
Okay.

. Two questions if I may. The first one is given that you may need to accelerate your broadband rollout and consequently the capital required, how tangible do you believe your 2010 cash flow protections will be in light of what you've communicated to the government as being the required capital to invest?

Well, one of the points that we have made consistently from three years ago was that our free cash flow, our CapEx estimates or targets were always asterisked, you know subject to whatever happens with broadband, what we now call NBN. So if for example, we – the government called up and said, hey, we are interested in hearing your thoughts about how the broadbandize Australia and et cetera, et cetera. And we said, okay, here's our thoughts. We'd probably invest up to $5 billion. You're talking about lets say, a plus or minus $1 billion a year of additional CapEx which would reduce the free cash flow and would increase whatever CapEx forecast that we've given to this point in time. And we've said that now for three years and that hasn't changed.
So, my point is given that you're out and you need to maintain a competitive network moving forward, would that not necessitate, you spending additional CapEx ahead of your 2010?

Well, we already have the best network in Australia. We already have the leading market position in Australia. So, I'm not as worried about that because the degree of difficulty of what is being suggested by others we'll deal with given our wireless platform, given our HFC platform, given the ADSL platform we already have in place plenty of options. And the good news is a big portion of the infrastructure is already there.

Just a last question, are you indicating a significant change in your channel strategy by following a road map or start to draw the analogy commander by rolling out your own stores on an expansive basis and if so, what might be the down sides to your channel partners?

Well, I'm not going to talk in any detail about what our strategy is because as you have hopefully seen over the last three or four years, we don't talk too much about what we're going to do, we just do it and then let everybody understand what we've done competitively. But we are very sensitive to our relationships with the partners that we have. And I think David Moffatt and his team are working hard at finding the right strategies that work both for Telstra and the partners. And you will see some of that play out during the year. And like I said, you'll see it play out and then we'll explain what we did.
Thank you.
Okay. Another call, please?
Thank you. We have a question from Mark Blackwell, Morgan Stanley.

Hi guys, just further to your early comments of the slowdown occurring really in the later part of the half. I'm wondering if you could confirm that it was sort of that latter part and what that implies for the second half? And secondly just, I note your guidance for revenue growth is retained and just given your comments on the economic outlook, I'm a bit surprised by that. I felt like there might be some softness in the top line as well as in the EBIT. So if could just comment on those two issues, that would be great.
I'll let John took this one.

Okay. What I said was yes in the latter part of the half, but I also said we have now six weeks trading and that hasn't changed from the last part of the first half. So, the first -- the latter part of the first half, the first six weeks of trading this year, suggest to us that there is a softening of the revenue and where I said it is, fixed voice and mobile voice. To your other question and I'll try to explain this also that we expected revenue fundamentally in the top end of the growth range and now we expect them in the lower end of the growth range and when you are talking about $26 billion business, this 1% is 260 million, so that's why we haven't changed the guidance on the top line.

I guess I would just add one other thing that this issue of volumes that I described a minute ago, we tied up a lot of our selling capacity by just simply answering calls. Now that we are on the other side of that, we are going to free up more capacity for outbound and inbound on the sale side, so the good news for our competitors was that there were some consumption of our capacity and the bad news is, look out, we are coming.
I look forward to some sales Telstra then. Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you. Next question is from Sachin Gupta, Nomura.

Yes, thanks very much. I have three questions. Firstly, I think John, I'm not sure if you've talked about this, but can you quantify how much are you factoring in for one off costs for the bushfires and the floods? And my second question is I think John, I think you mentioned that there will some further accelerated depreciation for Hong Kong CSL in the second half, I was wondering if you can quantify that place and if I recall I think you said there would be no more accelerated depreciation after the first half. I'm just wondering why is that continuing? And my third question is if you look at the PSTN retail revenues that's appears to be declining now its down 2%, But it seems to be driven more from lower usage rather than lower access lines. I was wondering is that a risk going forward and what are you factoring in your guidance, please. Thanks?

Yes, let me take the last one first because its probably the easier one. Yes, it is usage, that is impacting our view of the guidance and I think we saw that quite a few times. When you're a Telstra customer in economic hard times what can you control? You can control how you use the services as distinct from the cost of access and so on. So that in fact is what's happening. With respect to the costs of floods and fires and so on, what I did say was it's already in the tens of millions. So it's not huge numbers. There will be some capital requirement and there will be some expense requirement. So tens of millions of dollars with respect to that. With CSL New World accelerated depreciation and, yes, the network is taking a little longer to build in Hong Kong than we anticipated and so, therefore the accelerated depreciation has been spread over a longer period of time. You might say, well, that means it should be lower. But we've also have the FX impact on top of that which is unfortunately taken the advantage of it being spread over a bit of the longer period. So it now will go into the second half and with the impact of the FX difference that's being taken in to account. The guidance and what I said about second half it's about $70 million.

Yes, thanks. Can I just ask another question on guidance, then, if you to look at past results back in August, we had CapEx increase, no extra EBITDA growth slowing down, margins were still at 42%. Transformation still not complete, NBN is still pending. So I was wondering against this backdrop and given what we are asking in the macro-environment as well. How confident can one be with the 2010 guidance?

Well I guess, we're pretty confident in the sense that the things that we can control, which are costs. We've got basically everything tagged, everything binding, by date, by a lot of things internally. So that's the big part of what you going to see on EBITDA margins improvement right. We have communicated that, and that's what management can control. We can control -- some of the macro-economic variables and issues there. That's why John said we're looking at the lower end of our revenue guidance, but on the cost out. We know where it is, we know how to find it, we know how to get it. And I think that's where, we stand here today and say yes we're pretty confident about the 6 to $7 billion on free cash and EBITDA margins. And if it turns out that our guidance on EBITDA margins is 46 to 48 and we hit 45.7, right now we have at the margins that we were out today we are the best in the world. And very few companies in the world that are getting better EBITDA margins are going forward. So we think there is a relatively high degree of confidence here.
-- Sachin Gupta: Thank you.
Okay I think. We have one more question.
